awd_titl_txt: Promoting Productive Disciplinary Engagement and Learning with Open Problems and "Just-in-Time" Supports in Middle School Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
The study will contribute knowledge about how to support students' learning and engagement in mathematics using a digital curriculum platform. The goal of the project is to study how the use of open-ended problems and "just-in-time" supports in a digital platform can promote inquiry-based mathematics learning. Increasing numbers of schools are using digital curriculum for mathematics. "Just-in-time" supports will give the students options for seeking help as they are working on an open problem or give teachers the opportunity to generate prompts for students working in small groups as needed. The digital environment provides an opportunity for small groups of students to work on challenging tasks and decide when they need help.  The project is building on a widely adopted middle school mathematics curriculum and tasks that are being used in a range of settings.  The project will examine middle school students' mathematics learning and productive disciplinary engagement as well as teachers' role in the classroom environment. This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.

The research will investigate three questions. (1) How can productive disciplinary engagement be fostered in digital learning environments with open problems and "just-in-time" supports? How can student learning of mathematics be enhanced? (2) What is the nature of productive disciplinary engagement and student learning of mathematics at key development points in a connected sequence of problems and lesson goals? (3) What information do teachers draw upon when they use open problems and "just-in-time" supports? How do teachers adapt the supports for specific problems? It is situated in a design-based research framework for research relying on multiple qualitative and quantitative sources of data. The project will go through three cycles of design: prototype testing with students to investigate productive disciplinary engagement as a construct, classroom-based pilot testing to understand the teacher's role, and broader field testing to extend knowledge of how students' use open problems and "just-in-time" supports. The analysis of students' data will document how they problematize mathematics situations, how ideas are developed in a small group via students' positioning themselves in the conversation, and how students use disciplinary norms and arguments for their ideas.  Students' interactions with the tool, particularly the "just-in-time" supports will be incorporated to understand how ideas develop. Assessments will be used to document students' learning of the mathematics. The teachers' role will be analyzed via classroom video, interviews, and other artifacts of instruction.

por.por_cntn:
Promoting Productive Disciplinary Engagement and Learning with 
Open Problems and “Just-in-Time” Supports 
in Middle School Mathematics

Project Outcomes Report

Knowing how students engage productively in mathematics problems is critically important for researchers, teachers, and curriculum developers. The problems in which students engage form the perceptions they have about mathematics. In this project, the “openness” of mathematics problems refers to classroom activity devoted to the development of a mathematical idea that involves multiple methods, pathways, access points, and solutions. In problem-based classrooms, teachers reveal the embedded mathematics, position the mathematical goal of the problem within the underlying learning progression, and help students solve problems.

This project engaged in cycles of design, development, classroom testing, analysis, and refinement to develop and embed connected sequences of mathematics problems in a digital collaborative platform. The structure of the mathematics problems is different than conventional approaches to written tasks. The approach begins with an open, contextualized situation. Next, students consider new contexts, strategies, and examples of student work that focus on the mathematical learning goal. Students then reflect on their learning to summarize, generalize, and expand on the learning goal. The project also engaged in significant design research work for students to access “just-in-time” supports that were created and released by teachers. Teachers were able to access teacher-facing digital resources to monitor evidence of student thinking before, during, and after class, and create and send supports to students at the individual, small group, and whole class level. 

This project studied moments of collaborative work in small groups that can become potentially rich opportunities for students to engage and learn mathematics. Using video recordings, computer screen recordings, teacher interviews, and student interviews/surveys, the project generated knowledge about the nature of productive disciplinary engagement (PDE) and how students and teachers develop engagement across connected sequences of problems. Project research expanded on the concept of PDE and its four principles of problematizing, authority, accountability, and resources to create an analytical framework that characterizes multiple levels of engagement. The PDE framework can be used to describe student engagement in mathematics problems in paper-and-pencil or digital environments. This framework can also be used in teacher education and professional learning settings, particularly for supporting teachers to facilitate small group work and moment-to-moment discourse by attending to the four principles of PDE.

While prior research on PDE has centered on broad descriptions of classroom environments, project research found that students’ development was shaped to a greater extent by collaborative interactions with peers and the resources they used in the digital learning environment. Students collaborated with peers in both digital and physical spaces, often increasing student interactions with each other in the digital learning environment. The problem structure allowed students to seek out resources, including the curriculum, their peers, their peers’ digital mathematical work, the teacher, and the just-in-time supports created by the teacher. Since student opportunities for engagement and learning takes time, teachers need to allow students adequate time with each problem. Students were more likely to develop higher levels of PDE as the time provided for small group work increased. These research findings provide insights to how schools can use technology effectively to enhance the engagement in and learning of mathematics. Knowledge from the project has been disseminated through journal articles, research presentations, and newsletters.
